title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
‚ÄúWhy is the rum gone?!‚Äù ‚Äî Captain Jack Sparrow



Because Elizabeth burned it to signal the Navy.
She made a choice:

‚úÖ Rescue (high value to her)
‚ùå Rum (high value to Jack)

Same stuff. Different utilities. Different choices.
This is the entire chapter in one scene.





Every day you face the same dilemma as Captain Jack:

You have limited treasure üí∞ and unlimited wants.


Jack wants rum AND weapons AND a ship AND freedom
You want coffee AND Netflix AND gas AND textbooks
You can‚Äôt have it all ‚Üí you must CHOOSE

Today‚Äôs mission: Learn how economists think about these choices ‚Äî using rum ü•É and weapons ‚öîÔ∏è






The Pirate Goat Guarantee üêê



No calculus required. If you can add, subtract, multiply, and divide, you can do this. We‚Äôll take it one step at a time.





Utility = a made-up number that represents how much satisfaction you get from consuming something



You consume‚Ä¶
You feel‚Ä¶
Economists say‚Ä¶




First bottle of rum ü•É
AMAZING
High utility


Second bottle
Pretty good
Less utility


Fifth bottle
Meh
Even less utility


Tenth bottle
ü§¢
Almost zero utility



Key idea: We don‚Äôt measure utility in real units (there‚Äôs no ‚Äúsatisfaction-ometer‚Äù). We just need to rank things and compare them.






Note



Economists measure utility in fictional units called ‚Äúutils.‚Äù Think of them like points in a video game ‚Äî they don‚Äôt exist physically, but they help us keep score.





Marginal utility = the extra satisfaction from consuming one more unit




Show R Code
rum_data <- data.frame(
  bottles = 1:8,
  mu = c(50, 35, 25, 18, 12, 8, 5, 2)
)

ggplot(rum_data, aes(x = bottles, y = mu)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#8B4513", alpha = 0.85, width = 0.7) +
  geom_line(color = "#c0392b", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_point(color = "#c0392b", size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Marginal Utility of Rum",
    subtitle = "Each bottle makes Jack less happy than the last",
    x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É",
    y = "Marginal Utility (utils)"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:8) +
  theme_pirate














Bottle #
MU (utils)
Why?




1st
50
First rum in weeks!


2nd
35
Still great


3rd
25
Good but slowing down


4th
18
Starting to blur


5th
12
Jack‚Äôs swaying more


6th
8
Diminishing fast


7th
5
Why bother


8th
2
Almost zero






‚ÄúThe first bite of pizza is heaven. The eighth slice is regret.‚Äù ‚Äî Universal truth

This is the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility: each additional unit gives you LESS additional satisfaction. (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.1‚Äì25.2, pp.¬†494‚Äì495)



Total utility = the running total. Marginal utility = the change from each new unit.


Show R Code
rum_full <- data.frame(
  bottles = 0:8,
  tu = c(0, 50, 85, 110, 128, 140, 148, 153, 155),
  mu = c(NA, 50, 35, 25, 18, 12, 8, 5, 2)
)

library(patchwork)

p1 <- ggplot(rum_full, aes(x = bottles, y = tu)) +
  geom_line(color = "#2980b9", linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_point(color = "#2980b9", size = 3) +
  labs(title = "Total Utility", subtitle = "Keeps going up... but slower",
       x = "Bottles of Rum", y = "Total Utility (utils)") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 0:8) +
  theme_pirate

p2 <- ggplot(filter(rum_full, !is.na(mu)), aes(x = bottles, y = mu)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#e74c3c", alpha = 0.8, width = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "Marginal Utility", subtitle = "The EXTRA satisfaction per bottle",
       x = "Bottles of Rum", y = "Marginal Utility (utils)") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:8) +
  theme_pirate

p1 + p2















Read This Carefully



Total utility goes UP as long as marginal utility is POSITIVE. But it goes up by less and less each time. It‚Äôs like filling a bucket with a smaller cup each round ‚Äî the bucket still fills, just slower.





Let‚Äôs fill in this table together. No tricks. Just adding.



Bottle
Marginal Utility
Total Utility




0
‚Äî
0


1
50
0 + 50 = ?


2
35
50 + 35 = ?


3
25
85 + 25 = ?


4
18
110 + 18 = ?






Bottle
Marginal Utility
Total Utility




0
‚Äî
0


1
50
50


2
35
85


3
25
110


4
18
128




Total utility at bottle N = Total utility at bottle (N-1) + Marginal utility of bottle N

That‚Äôs it. You‚Äôre just adding one number to the running total each time. üéâ



Jack doesn‚Äôt just want rum. He also needs weapons to defend the Black Pearl.


Show R Code
weapons_data <- data.frame(
  weapons = 1:8,
  mu_w = c(60, 45, 32, 22, 15, 10, 6, 3)
)

rum_plot <- ggplot(rum_data, aes(x = bottles, y = mu)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#8B4513", alpha = 0.85, width = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "MU of Rum ü•É", x = "Bottles", y = "Marginal Utility") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:8) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 65)) +
  theme_pirate

weapon_plot <- ggplot(weapons_data, aes(x = weapons, y = mu_w)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#2c3e50", alpha = 0.85, width = 0.7) +
  labs(title = "MU of Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è", x = "Weapons", y = "Marginal Utility") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:8) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 65)) +
  theme_pirate

rum_plot + weapon_plot









Both goods have diminishing marginal utility. But now Jack has a real problem:

If he spends his gold on rum, he can‚Äôt spend it on weapons. That‚Äôs the trade-off.










üö® THE MOST COMMON MISTAKE üö®



Students see a graph with ‚ÄúRum‚Äù on one axis and ‚ÄúWeapons‚Äù on the other and think: ‚ÄúWhere are the dollars?‚Äù
The dollars are GONE. You already spent them. The axes show you what you GOT for your money ‚Äî physical goods, not cash.


Think of it this way:

Jack raids a treasure chest and finds 100 gold coins üí∞
Rum costs 10 gold per bottle
Weapons cost 20 gold per weapon
He must spend it all (pirates don‚Äôt save ‚Äî that‚Äôs macro üòâ)

The question is: How many bottles of rum and how many weapons should he buy?

Every bottle of rum Jack buys means he gave up some weapons. Every weapon means he gave up some rum. That‚Äôs opportunity cost ‚Äî and it‚Äôs what the graph shows!

text:
üö® THE MOST COMMON MISTAKE üö®



Students see a graph with ‚ÄúRum‚Äù on one axis and ‚ÄúWeapons‚Äù on the other and think: ‚ÄúWhere are the dollars?‚Äù

Jack raids a treasure chest and finds 100 gold coins üí∞
Rum costs 10 gold per bottle

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
section: 2.1 üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è Jack‚Äôs Budget: Setting Up the Equation
text:
2.1 üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è Jack‚Äôs Budget: Setting Up the Equation
Let‚Äôs get really specific. Here‚Äôs what Jack is working with:



What Jack has
Value




üí∞ Income (treasure)
100 gold coins


ü•É Price of rum
10 gold per bottle


‚öîÔ∏è Price of weapons
20 gold per weapon



The budget constraint says: everything you spend must add up to your income.
\[
\underbrace{P_{\text{Rum}}}_{\text{price of rum}} \times \underbrace{Q_{\text{Rum}}}_{\text{bottles you buy}} + \underbrace{P_{\text{Weapons}}}_{\text{price of weapons}} \times \underbrace{Q_{\text{Weapons}}}_{\text{weapons you buy}} = \underbrace{I}_{\text{income}}
\]
Plugging in Jack‚Äôs numbers:
\[
10 \times Q_{\text{Rum}} + 20 \times Q_{\text{Weapons}} = 100
\]






English Translation



‚ÄúThe gold I spend on rum PLUS the gold I spend on weapons EQUALS all my gold.‚Äù

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.2 Finding the Intercepts (The Easy Points)
To draw the budget line, we need two points. The easiest two points are the intercepts ‚Äî where Jack spends ALL his gold on just one good.


2.2.1 ü•É All Rum, No Weapons
Set \(Q_{\text{Weapons}} = 0\):
\[
10 \times Q_{\text{Rum}} + 20 \times (0) = 100
\] \[
10 \times Q_{\text{Rum}} = 100
\] \[
Q_{\text{Rum}} = \frac{100}{10} = \mathbf{10}
\]
Point: (10 bottles, 0 weapons)


2.2.2 ‚öîÔ∏è All Weapons, No Rum
Set \(Q_{\text{Rum}} = 0\):
\[
10 \times (0) + 20 \times Q_{\text{Weapons}} = 100
\] \[
20 \times Q_{\text{Weapons}} = 100
\] \[
Q_{\text{Weapons}} = \frac{100}{20} = \mathbf{5}
\]
Point: (0 bottles, 5 weapons)








The Intercept Shortcut üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è



Intercept = Income √∑ Price of that good.

Rum intercept: 100 √∑ 10 = 10
Weapons intercept: 100 √∑ 20 = 5

That‚Äôs it. Division. You‚Äôve got this.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.3 Drawing the Budget Line


Show R Code
budget_df <- data.frame(
  rum = c(0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10),
  weapons = c(5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0)
)

ggplot(budget_df, aes(x = rum, y = weapons)) +
  geom_line(color = "#2c3e50", linewidth = 2) +
  geom_point(color = "#c0392b", size = 4) +
  # Label intercepts
  annotate("text", x = 10.3, y = 0.3, label = "All Rum\n(10, 0)",
           fontface = "bold", size = 4, color = "#8B4513") +
  annotate("text", x = 0.8, y = 5.2, label = "All Weapons\n(0, 5)",
           fontface = "bold", size = 4, color = "#2c3e50") +
  # Shade the affordable region
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = 0, ymax = weapons), fill = "#3498db", alpha = 0.15) +
  annotate("text", x = 3, y = 1.5, label = "Affordable\nBundles",
           size = 5, color = "#2980b9", fontface = "italic") +
  labs(
    title = "Jack's Budget Constraint",
    subtitle = "Income = 100g | Rum = 10g/bottle | Weapons = 20g each",
    x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É",
    y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 0:10) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = 0:5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 11), ylim = c(0, 6)) +
  theme_pirate










On the line = spending ALL your income (efficient pirate ‚úÖ)
Inside the shaded area = affordable but not spending everything (wasteful pirate üòí)
Outside the line = can‚Äôt afford it (sad pirate üò¢)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.4 The Slope = The Price Ratio
The slope of the budget line tells you the real trade-off between goods.
\[
\text{Slope} = -\frac{P_{\text{Rum}}}{P_{\text{Weapons}}} = -\frac{10}{20} = -\frac{1}{2}
\]






What Does -1/2 Mean?



For every 1 extra bottle of rum Jack buys, he gives up 1/2 a weapon.
Or: For every 1 extra weapon, he gives up 2 bottles of rum.
The slope IS the opportunity cost. (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.4, p.¬†497)


Let‚Äôs verify with the table:



Rum ü•É
Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è
Check: 10√óR + 20√óW = ?




0
5
0 + 100 = ‚úÖ 100


2
4
20 + 80 = ‚úÖ 100


4
3
40 + 60 = ‚úÖ 100


6
2
60 + 40 = ‚úÖ 100


8
1
80 + 20 = ‚úÖ 100


10
0
100 + 0 = ‚úÖ 100



Every point adds up to 100. That‚Äôs the whole point of the budget line. ‚úÖ

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.5 What Moves the Budget Line?


Show R Code
library(patchwork)

# Income change
inc_df <- bind_rows(
  data.frame(rum = c(0, 10), weapons = c(5, 0), label = "I = 100g"),
  data.frame(rum = c(0, 15), weapons = c(7.5, 0), label = "I = 150g (raise!)"),
  data.frame(rum = c(0, 5), weapons = c(2.5, 0), label = "I = 50g (taxed!)")
)

p_inc <- ggplot(inc_df, aes(x = rum, y = weapons, color = label)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#2ecc71", "#2c3e50", "#e74c3c")) +
  labs(title = "Income Changes", subtitle = "Line shifts parallel",
       x = "Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è", color = NULL) +
  theme_pirate + theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.text = element_text(size = 10))

# Price change (rum gets cheaper)
price_df <- bind_rows(
  data.frame(rum = c(0, 10), weapons = c(5, 0), label = "P_rum = 10g"),
  data.frame(rum = c(0, 20), weapons = c(5, 0), label = "P_rum = 5g (sale!)")
)

p_price <- ggplot(price_df, aes(x = rum, y = weapons, color = label)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#2c3e50", "#e67e22")) +
  labs(title = "Rum Price Falls", subtitle = "Line pivots outward from weapons intercept",
       x = "Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è", color = NULL) +
  theme_pirate + theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.text = element_text(size = 10))

p_inc + p_price

















What changes?
What happens to the line?
Why?




Income goes UP
Shifts outward (parallel)
More gold = more of everything


Income goes DOWN
Shifts inward (parallel)
Less gold = less of everything


Price of rum FALLS
Pivots outward at weapons intercept
Same weapons, but MORE rum affordable


Price of rum RISES
Pivots inward at weapons intercept
Same weapons, but LESS rum affordable



(Cowen & Tabarrok, Figs. 25.5‚Äì25.6, pp.¬†498‚Äì499)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.6 üêê Practice: Jack Gets a Raise
Jack‚Äôs income increases from 100 gold to 200 gold. Prices stay the same.
Step 1: New rum intercept = ?
\[Q_{\text{Rum}} = \frac{200}{10} = \mathbf{20 \text{ bottles}}\]
Step 2: New weapons intercept = ?
\[Q_{\text{Weapons}} = \frac{200}{20} = \mathbf{10 \text{ weapons}}\]
Step 3: New slope = ?
\[\text{Slope} = -\frac{P_R}{P_W} = -\frac{10}{20} = -\frac{1}{2} \quad \text{(unchanged!)}\]

üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è The line shifts out, but the slope stays the same. More gold doesn‚Äôt change the relative cost of rum vs.¬†weapons ‚Äî it just lets you buy more of both.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
2.7 GOOD NEWS EVERYONE! üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è


‚ÄúWhy is the rum ALWAYS gone?‚Äù

Because, Jack, you keep maximizing utility at a corner solution.
Now that we understand the budget constraint ‚Äî let‚Äôs figure out which bundle on that line makes Jack the happiest.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
3.1 The Big Question
Jack‚Äôs budget constraint shows all the bundles he can afford.
But which one should he actually choose?
The one that gives him the MOST total utility.
But how do we find it? Two methods:

üßÆ The MU/$ method (the workhorse ‚Äî we‚Äôll master this)
üìê The graphical method (indifference curves ‚Äî we‚Äôll see the intuition)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
3.2 The ‚ÄúBang for Your Buck‚Äù Method
Here‚Äôs the secret to smart shopping ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre a pirate or an Aggie:






The Utility Maximization Rule



Spend your next gold coin on whichever good gives you the most extra utility per gold coin spent.
\[
\frac{MU_{\text{Rum}}}{P_{\text{Rum}}} = \frac{MU_{\text{Weapons}}}{P_{\text{Weapons}}}
\]
When this condition holds, you cannot rearrange your spending to get more utility.


In English: If your last gold coin spent on rum gave you 3 utils per coin, and your last gold coin on weapons gave you 5 utils per coin‚Ä¶ you should have bought more weapons!
You keep adjusting until both ratios are equal. (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.3, p.¬†496)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
3.3 Let‚Äôs Walk Through It ‚Äî Slowly

How to Calculate MU/$



It‚Äôs just division: Marginal Utility √∑ Price.

MU of 1st rum bottle = 50. Price = 10. So 50 √∑ 10 = 5.0 utils per gold coin.
MU of 1st weapon = 60. Price = 20. So 60 √∑ 20 = 3.0 utils per gold coin.

That‚Äôs it! No fancy math. Just ‚Äúhow many utils do I get for each gold coin?‚Äù

Note

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
section: 3.5 ‚ò†Ô∏è What Happens If Jack is NOT Optimal?
text:
3.5 ‚ò†Ô∏è What Happens If Jack is NOT Optimal?
Suppose Jack is being stubborn and spends all 100g on weapons:

He gets 5 weapons. MU of 5th weapon = 15. MU/$= 15/20 = 0.75
If he gave up the 5th weapon (saves 20g), he could buy 2 bottles of rum
Those 2 bottles give him: 50 + 35 = 85 utils
He only lost: 15 utils from the weapon

Net gain: 85 - 15 = 70 extra utils! üéâ

This is exactly the logic from the textbook‚Äôs Thai takeout example (Cowen & Tabarrok, Ch. 25, Problem 1, p.¬†494): giving up the 10th Thai meal (MU/$ = 0.5) to buy two movies (MU/$ = 10) is a massive improvement.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
section: 3.6 üêê You Try: Is This Bundle Optimal?
text:
3.6 üêê You Try: Is This Bundle Optimal?
Jack has 100g. Rum = 10g. Weapons = 20g. He‚Äôs currently holding 6 Rum and 2 Weapons.
Step 1: Does the budget work?
(6 √ó 10) + (2 √ó 20) = 60 + 40 = 100 ‚úÖ
Step 2: Check MU/$ at these quantities:

MU of 6th Rum = 8 ‚Üí MU/$ = 8/10 = 0.8
MU of 2nd Weapon = 45 ‚Üí MU/$ = 45/20 = 2.25

Weapons MU/$ (2.25) >> Rum MU/$ (0.8) ‚ùå NOT optimal!
Jack should buy fewer rum, more weapons until the ratios equalize.






The Golden Rule



If MU/$ is higher for one good, buy MORE of it (and less of the other). Keep adjusting until MU/$ is equal across goods.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
4.1 What‚Äôs an Indifference Curve?
An indifference curve connects all bundles that give Jack the same level of utility.


Show R Code
# Indifference curves as hyperbolas
ic_df <- data.frame(rum = seq(0.5, 10, 0.1)) |>
  mutate(
    IC1 = 4 / rum,
    IC2 = 8 / rum,
    IC3 = 14 / rum
  )

ggplot(ic_df, aes(x = rum)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC1), color = "#3498db", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC2), color = "#2ecc71", linewidth = 1.2) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC3), color = "#e74c3c", linewidth = 1.2) +
  annotate("text", x = 8, y = 0.7, label = "U1 (low)", color = "#3498db",
           fontface = "bold", size = 4.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 8, y = 1.3, label = "U2 (medium)", color = "#2ecc71",
           fontface = "bold", size = 4.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 8, y = 2.2, label = "U3 (high!)", color = "#e74c3c",
           fontface = "bold", size = 4.5) +
  annotate("segment", x = 5, y = 2, xend = 7, yend = 3,
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm")),
           color = "#555", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = 6.5, y = 3.3, label = "Happier ‚Üí",
           fontface = "bold", size = 5, color = "#555") +
  labs(
    title = "Jack's Indifference Curves",
    subtitle = "Higher curves = more utility = happier pirate",
    x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É",
    y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è"
  ) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 6)) +
  theme_pirate









Key rules: Higher = better. They never cross. They‚Äôre bowed inward (convex). (Cowen & Tabarrok, Figs. 25.7‚Äì25.8, pp.¬†500‚Äì501)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
section: 4.2 Why Are They Curved? The MRS
text:
4.2 Why Are They Curved? The MRS
The curve shape reflects the Marginal Rate of Substitution (MRS):

How many weapons would Jack willingly give up for 1 more bottle of rum?



Show R Code
mrs_df <- data.frame(rum = seq(0.5, 9, 0.1)) |>
  mutate(weapons = 10 / rum)

ggplot(mrs_df, aes(x = rum, y = weapons)) +
  geom_line(color = "#2ecc71", linewidth = 1.5) +
  # Point A: few rum, lots of weapons
  annotate("point", x = 1, y = 10, size = 4, color = "#c0392b") +
  annotate("text", x = 1.8, y = 10.3, label = "A: Lots of weapons,\nlittle rum",
           size = 3.5, color = "#c0392b") +
  annotate("segment", x = 1, y = 10, xend = 2, yend = 10, color = "#c0392b",
           linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("segment", x = 2, y = 10, xend = 2, yend = 5, color = "#c0392b",
           linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("text", x = 2.5, y = 7.5, label = "Give up 5 weapons\nfor 1 rum",
           size = 3, color = "#c0392b") +
  # Point B: more balanced
  annotate("point", x = 5, y = 2, size = 4, color = "#2980b9") +
  annotate("text", x = 6.2, y = 2.3, label = "B: More balanced",
           size = 3.5, color = "#2980b9") +
  annotate("segment", x = 5, y = 2, xend = 6, yend = 2, color = "#2980b9",
           linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("segment", x = 6, y = 2, xend = 6, yend = 10/6, color = "#2980b9",
           linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("text", x = 6.7, y = 1.5, label = "Give up 0.3 weapons\nfor 1 rum",
           size = 3, color = "#2980b9") +
  labs(title = "The MRS Changes Along the Curve",
       subtitle = "You'll give up less of what you already have little of",
       x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 12)) +
  theme_pirate









At point A: Jack has tons of weapons, almost no rum. He‚Äôd trade away 5 weapons for 1 rum. At point B: More balanced. He‚Äôd only trade 0.3 weapons for 1 rum.

The less you have of something, the more valuable the next unit is. (Cowen & Tabarrok, Ch. 25 solution to Q4, pp.¬†500‚Äì501)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
4.3 The Consumer‚Äôs Optimum üéØ
The best bundle is where the budget constraint just barely touches the highest possible indifference curve.


Show R Code
opt_df <- data.frame(rum = seq(0.3, 10, 0.05)) |>
  mutate(
    budget = 5 - 0.5 * rum,
    IC_low = 3.5 / rum,
    IC_opt = 6.25 / rum,
    IC_high = 10 / rum
  )

ggplot(opt_df, aes(x = rum)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = budget), color = "#2c3e50", linewidth = 2) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC_low), color = "#bdc3c7", linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC_opt), color = "#2ecc71", linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_line(aes(y = IC_high), color = "#e74c3c", linewidth = 1, linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("point", x = 5, y = 2.5, size = 5, color = "#e67e22") +
  annotate("text", x = 6.2, y = 3, label = "OPTIMAL\nBUNDLE ‚òÖ",
           fontface = "bold", size = 5, color = "#e67e22") +
  annotate("text", x = 8.5, y = 0.6, label = "Too low\n(affordable but sad)",
           size = 3.5, color = "#bdc3c7") +
  annotate("text", x = 8.5, y = 1.5, label = "Just right!",
           size = 3.5, color = "#2ecc71", fontface = "bold") +
  annotate("text", x = 8.5, y = 3.5, label = "Too expensive\n(can't afford)",
           size = 3.5, color = "#e74c3c") +
  labs(
    title = "The Consumer's Optimum",
    subtitle = "Highest indifference curve that just touches the budget line",
    x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è"
  ) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 10), ylim = c(0, 6)) +
  theme_pirate









At the tangency point (‚òÖ): slope of IC = slope of budget line, which means MRS = Price ratio (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.9, p.¬†502)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
section: 4.4 What the Optimum Means in English
text:
4.4 What the Optimum Means in English
At the optimal bundle, two things are true simultaneously:
1. You‚Äôre ON the budget line ‚Üí spending all your income
2. MRS = Price Ratio ‚Üí your personal trade-off matches the market trade-off
\[
\underbrace{\frac{MU_{\text{Rum}}}{MU_{\text{Weapons}}}}_{\text{how YOU value rum vs. weapons}} = \underbrace{\frac{P_{\text{Rum}}}{P_{\text{Weapons}}}}_{\text{how the MARKET values rum vs. weapons}}
\]
If these don‚Äôt match, you can make yourself happier by trading.






Note



This is the graphical version of the MU/$ rule. Same answer, prettier picture. The MU/$ approach says: equalize the bang-per-buck. The tangency approach says: equalize personal valuation with market valuation. Same thing. Two languages.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
5.1 üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è Price of Rum Falls! (Raid successful üéâ)
Suppose rum drops from 10g to 5g per bottle. Weapons still 20g. Income still 100g.


Show R Code
change_df <- data.frame(rum = c(0, 10, NA, 0, 20)) |>
  mutate(
    weapons_old = c(5, 0, NA, NA, NA),
    weapons_new = c(NA, NA, NA, 5, 0)
  )

ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 5, xend = 10, yend = 0),
               color = "#2c3e50", linewidth = 1.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 5, xend = 20, yend = 0),
               color = "#e67e22", linewidth = 2) +
  annotate("text", x = 5, y = 3.5, label = "OLD: Rum = 10g",
           color = "#2c3e50", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  annotate("text", x = 13, y = 2, label = "NEW: Rum = 5g",
           color = "#e67e22", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  annotate("text", x = 0.8, y = 5.3, label = "Same intercept\n(weapons unchanged)",
           size = 3.5, color = "#555") +
  annotate("segment", x = 10, y = -0.1, xend = 20, yend = -0.1,
           arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.3, "cm")),
           color = "#e67e22", linewidth = 1) +
  annotate("text", x = 15, y = -0.4, label = "Can buy more rum!",
           color = "#e67e22", fontface = "bold", size = 4) +
  labs(
    title = "Budget Constraint Pivots When Rum Price Falls",
    subtitle = "Weapons intercept unchanged, rum intercept doubles",
    x = "Bottles of Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 20, 2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = 0:5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 21), ylim = c(-0.5, 6)) +
  theme_pirate













Old
New




Rum intercept
100/10 = 10
100/5 = 20


Weapons intercept
100/20 = 5
100/20 = 5


Slope
-10/20 = -1/2
-5/20 = -1/4



Jack can now reach a higher indifference curve ‚Üí more utility! üéâ (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.10, p.¬†503)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
5.2 Income vs.¬†Substitution Effects
When the price of rum falls, TWO things happen simultaneously:


5.2.1 üîÑ Substitution Effect
Rum is relatively cheaper now ‚Üí Jack substitutes toward rum and away from weapons.
‚ÄúRum‚Äôs on sale! Buy more rum!‚Äù


5.2.2 üí∞ Income Effect
Jack‚Äôs real purchasing power increased (same gold buys more) ‚Üí he can buy more of BOTH goods.
‚ÄúI feel richer! More of everything!‚Äù


For rum (the good whose price fell):

Substitution effect ‚Üí more rum ‚úÖ
Income effect ‚Üí more rum ‚úÖ (assuming rum is a normal good)
Total: definitely more rum

For weapons (the other good):

Substitution effect ‚Üí fewer weapons ‚ùå
Income effect ‚Üí more weapons ‚úÖ
Total: ambiguous ‚Äî depends which effect is stronger

(Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.11, p.¬†504)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
5.3 üêê Practice: Income Drops
A royal tax reduces Jack‚Äôs treasure from 100g to 60g. Prices unchanged (Rum=10g, Weapons=20g).
Find the new intercepts:

Rum intercept: 60 √∑ 10 = 6 bottles
Weapons intercept: 60 √∑ 20 = 3 weapons
Slope: -10/20 = -1/2 (unchanged ‚Äî only income changed!)

What happened to the budget line?

It shifted inward, parallel to the original. Same slope, lower intercepts. Jack can afford less of everything. üò¢ (Cowen & Tabarrok, Fig. 25.5, p.¬†498)

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
5.4 Deriving Demand from Utility
Here‚Äôs the payoff: Utility theory IS demand theory.
When the price of rum falls (10g ‚Üí 5g), Jack buys more rum. That‚Äôs one point on his demand curve.


Show R Code
p_budget <- ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 5, xend = 10, yend = 0),
               color = "#2c3e50", linewidth = 1.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_segment(aes(x = 0, y = 5, xend = 20, yend = 0),
               color = "#e67e22", linewidth = 1.5) +
  annotate("point", x = 4, y = 3, size = 4, color = "#2c3e50") +
  annotate("point", x = 10, y = 2.5, size = 4, color = "#e67e22") +
  annotate("text", x = 4.5, y = 3.4, label = "A", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  annotate("text", x = 10.5, y = 2.9, label = "B", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  labs(title = "Budget + Indifference Curves",
       x = "Rum ü•É", y = "Weapons ‚öîÔ∏è") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 21), ylim = c(0, 6)) +
  theme_pirate

p_demand <- ggplot() +
  annotate("point", x = 4, y = 10, size = 4, color = "#2c3e50") +
  annotate("point", x = 10, y = 5, size = 4, color = "#e67e22") +
  annotate("text", x = 4.5, y = 10.5, label = "A", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  annotate("text", x = 10.5, y = 5.5, label = "B", fontface = "bold", size = 5) +
  geom_segment(aes(x = 4, y = 10, xend = 10, yend = 5),
               color = "#c0392b", linewidth = 1.5) +
  labs(title = "Jack's Demand for Rum",
       x = "Quantity of Rum ü•É", y = "Price of Rum (gold)") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 15), ylim = c(0, 15)) +
  theme_pirate

p_budget + p_demand










Point A: Price = 10g ‚Üí Jack buys 4 rum (optimal bundle)
Point B: Price = 5g ‚Üí Jack buys 10 rum (new optimal bundle)
Connect the dots ‚Üí DEMAND CURVE! üìâ


Demand slopes downward because of diminishing marginal utility and the substitution/income effects. Utility theory explains why demand curves look the way they do.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
6.1 The Pirate Goat Summary üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏èüêê








Concept
What It Means
Jack‚Äôs Version




Utility
Satisfaction from consuming
How happy rum makes him


Marginal Utility
Extra satisfaction per unit
The 1st rum is amazing, the 8th is meh


Diminishing MU
Each unit adds less
Law of ‚Äútoo much of a good thing‚Äù


Budget Constraint
All affordable combos
What 100g of treasure can buy


Slope = -Px/Py
The market trade-off
1 rum costs 1/2 weapon


MU/$ equalization
How to maximize utility
Spend where bang-for-buck is highest


Indifference Curve
Same-utility bundles
Doesn‚Äôt care between 4R+3W or 6R+2W


Tangency = Optimum
MRS = Price Ratio
Personal value = market value


Price change ‚Üí Demand
Optimal bundles at different prices
The demand curve!

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
6.2 The Real-World Connection
This isn‚Äôt just about pirates. Every choice you make is this model:

üçï Pizza vs.¬†üåÆ Tacos with your meal plan
üì± Phone upgrade vs.¬†üëü New shoes with your paycheck
üìö Study time vs.¬†üéÆ Gaming time (time is a budget too!)
‚òï Daily Starbucks vs.¬†üé¨ Weekend movies with your fun money


Every time you ask ‚ÄúIs this worth it?‚Äù you‚Äôre comparing MU/$. You already do utility maximization ‚Äî now you just know the formal framework.







Note



Remember Marcus from the textbook (Ch. 25, Q12): he has a money constraint AND a time constraint. Real life has multiple budget constraints ‚Äî time, money, energy ‚Äî and you optimize across all of them.

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
7.1 Setting It Up with Calculus






üìù This section is OPTIONAL



Nothing in this appendix will be on your exams. This is for students who want to see what‚Äôs happening ‚Äúunder the hood.‚Äù If calculus gives you hives, skip it with zero guilt.


Suppose Jack‚Äôs utility function is:
\[U(R, W) = R^{0.6} \cdot W^{0.4}\]
where \(R\) = rum and \(W\) = weapons. His constraint:
\[10R + 20W = 100\]

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
7.2 The Lagrangian Method
We want to maximize \(U(R,W)\) subject to the budget constraint.
Set up the Lagrangian:
\[\mathcal{L} = R^{0.6} W^{0.4} - \lambda(10R + 20W - 100)\]
Take partial derivatives and set them to zero:
\[\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial R} = 0.6 R^{-0.4} W^{0.4} - 10\lambda = 0\]
\[\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial W} = 0.4 R^{0.6} W^{-0.6} - 20\lambda = 0\]
\[\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial \lambda} = 100 - 10R - 20W = 0\]

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
7.3 Solving for the Optimum
Divide the first equation by the second:
\[\frac{0.6 R^{-0.4} W^{0.4}}{0.4 R^{0.6} W^{-0.6}} = \frac{10\lambda}{20\lambda}\]
\[\frac{0.6}{0.4} \cdot \frac{W}{R} = \frac{1}{2}\]
\[\frac{3}{2} \cdot \frac{W}{R} = \frac{1}{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad W = \frac{R}{3}\]
Plug back into the budget constraint:
\[10R + 20\left(\frac{R}{3}\right) = 100\] \[10R + \frac{20R}{3} = 100\] \[\frac{50R}{3} = 100 \quad \Rightarrow \quad R = 6, \quad W = 2\]
Optimal bundle: 6 Rum, 2 Weapons ‚Üí \(U = 6^{0.6} \cdot 2^{0.4} \approx 4.13\) utils

The calculus confirms what the MU/$ method finds ‚Äî just with more precision and fewer tables. Same economics, different toolkit. üîß

title: Consumer Choice: A Pirate‚Äôs Guide to Utility Theory
text:
7.4 üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏è Final Words from the Captain


What Jack Sparrow taught us today:

You can‚Äôt have all the rum AND all the weapons
The budget constraint shows your real trade-offs
Smart pirates equalize ‚Äúbang for your buck‚Äù
Price changes create new opportunities
The demand curve comes FROM utility maximization

Next class: We‚Äôll build worksheets with these concepts and practice until the MU/$ of studying econ equals the MU/$ of everything else you could be doing.




‚ÄúBut why is the rum gone?!‚Äù

Because you spent your budget optimally, Captain. üè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏èüêê




7.4.1 References

Cowen, T., & Tabarrok, A. (2024). Modern Principles: Microeconomics (6th ed.). Worth Publishers. Chapter 25: Consumer Choice.
Figures referenced: 25.1‚Äì25.12, pp.¬†494‚Äì506.

title: About The Teaching GOAT
text:
The Teaching GOAT (Generated Online Academic Teaching) is an automated system for creating and managing economics course materials at New Mexico State University.


The Teaching GOAT is a modern, reproducible course management platform built with:

Quarto ‚Äì Reproducible documents combining narrative and code
R ‚Äì Statistical computing and automation
GitHub ‚Äì Version control and collaborative development
Bootstrap ‚Äì Responsive web design framework




‚ú® Automated Course Generation - Generates syllabi, schedules, and course materials from configuration files - Consistent formatting across all courses - Version-controlled content with full Git history
üìö Organized Course Structure - Each course has dedicated sections for lectures, assignments, and resources - Student-friendly navigation with clear course hierarchies - Mobile-responsive design for all devices
üîÑ Reproducible & Maintainable - All content generated from R scripts and configuration data - Easy to update and redeploy - Transparent build process
üåê Publicly Accessible - Hosted on GitHub Pages for free, permanent access - All materials publicly available - Searchable course navigation



Each course includes:

Syllabus ‚Äì Course policies, requirements, and learning outcomes
Schedule ‚Äì Week-by-week topics, readings, and due dates
Lectures ‚Äì Lecture notes, slides, and supplementary materials
Worksheets ‚Äì Practice problems and problem sets
Resources ‚Äì Additional readings, datasets, and tools




Frontend: - Quarto rendering to static HTML - Bootstrap-based responsive design - Lux theme for professional appearance
Backend: - R automation scripts for content generation - CSV-based course configuration - GitHub Actions for continuous deployment
Hosting: - GitHub Pages for static site hosting - Custom domain support available - Automatic HTTPS/SSL



Dr.¬†Meghan Downes teaches economics at New Mexico State University. Her research and teaching focus on monetary economics, financial systems, and economic policy.
Contact Information: - Email: cmdownes@nmsu.edu - Office Hours: By appointment - GitHub: meghandownes



For Students: 1. Find your course in the course list 2. Review the syllabus and schedule 3. Access lecture materials and assignments 4. Submit work through Canvas or GitHub as directed
For Instructors: 1. Clone the repository: https://github.com/meghandownes/the-teaching-goat 2. Modify the data/courses.csv to add your courses 3. Run the build script: Rscript scripts/07-build.R 4. Preview with quarto preview 5. Deploy with quarto publish



The complete source code for this site is available on GitHub:
meghandownes/the-teaching-goat
All materials are licensed under the MIT License. Feel free to fork, modify, and adapt for your own teaching.



This site does not collect personal information. Analytics are handled securely and do not track individual users.

No cookies or tracking pixels
No third-party data collection
All content publicly accessible
Student work submissions through Canvas (separate, secured platform)




For questions about course content: - Email: cmdownes@nmsu.edu - Canvas: Check your course Canvas site for direct messaging
For technical issues with this site: - GitHub Issues: Report a bug - Pull Requests: Suggest improvements

The Teaching GOAT ¬© 2026 Dr.¬†Meghan Downes, New Mexico State University
Built with Quarto, R, and GitHub

title: Principles of Microeconomics
text:
Course Description
ECON 2120G. Microeconomics Principles
3 Credits (3)
This course will provide a broad overview of microeconomics. Microeconomics is the study of issues specific to households, firms, or industries with an emphasis on the role of markets. Topics discussed will include household and firm behavior, demand and supply,government intervention, market structures, and the efficient allocation of resources.

title: Principles of Microeconomics
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing this course, you will be able to:

Understand and apply key concepts in principles of microeconomics
Analyze real-world economic problems using course material
Communicate economic ideas clearly in writing and discussion
Use data and quantitative methods to support economic arguments

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
In 2025, the United States has a total GDP (PPP) of about $30.6 trillion, China leads the world at $41.0 trillion, and Norway ‚Äî a country of just 5.5 million people ‚Äî punches far above its weight. But GDP alone is misleading. When we adjust for population, prices, and inflation, a radically different picture emerges.
This lecture uses three countries ‚Äî the United States, China, and Norway ‚Äî as a running comparison to explore:

How we measure economic output (nominal ‚Üí real ‚Üí per capita ‚Üí PPP)
Why growth rates matter more than levels
What institutions and ideas drive long-run growth (Cowen & Tabarrok, Chs. 7‚Äì8)

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
2.1 Nominal GDP
Nominal GDP is the total value of all final goods and services produced in an economy, measured in current prices for a given year.
\[
\text{Nominal GDP} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} P_i \times Q_i \tag{1}
\]
where \(P_i\) is the current price of good \(i\) and \(Q_i\) is the quantity produced.
Problem: Nominal GDP rises when prices rise, even if output doesn‚Äôt change. If prices doubled and production stayed flat, nominal GDP would double ‚Äî but the country isn‚Äôt actually richer. We need to strip out inflation.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
2.2 Real GDP: Adjusting for Inflation
Real GDP removes the effect of price changes by using a GDP deflator ‚Äî a price index that measures the overall price level relative to a base year.
\[
\text{Real GDP} = \frac{\text{Nominal GDP}}{\text{GDP Deflator} / 100} \tag{2}
\]
Alternatively, if the deflator is expressed as a decimal multiplier:
\[
\text{Real GDP} = \frac{\text{Nominal GDP}}{1 + d} \tag{3}
\]
where \(d\) is the inflation rate captured by the deflator.


Code
# Example: US Nominal GDP and deflator
nominal_gdp <- 29168  # billions, approximate 2024
deflator <- 123.5     # base year = 2017 = 100

real_gdp <- nominal_gdp / (deflator / 100)

tibble(
  Measure = c("Nominal GDP (2024)", "GDP Deflator (2017 base)", "Real GDP (2017 dollars)"),
  Value = c(paste0("$", format(nominal_gdp, big.mark = ","), " B"),
            deflator,
            paste0("$", format(round(real_gdp), big.mark = ","), " B"))
) %>%
  kable(caption = "Converting Nominal to Real GDP: United States") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)



Converting Nominal to Real GDP: United States


Measure
Value




Nominal GDP (2024)
$29,168 B


GDP Deflator (2017 base)
123.5


Real GDP (2017 dollars)
$23,618 B











Why Real GDP Matters



Between 2000 and 2024, US nominal GDP roughly tripled. But much of that was inflation. Real GDP roughly doubled ‚Äî still impressive, but a very different story. Always use real GDP for comparisons across time.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
section: 2.3 Per Capita GDP: Adjusting for Population
text:
2.3 Per Capita GDP: Adjusting for Population
A country with 1.4 billion people and $18 trillion in GDP is not richer per person than a country with 340 million people and $29 trillion. To compare living standards, divide by population.
\[
\text{GDP per capita} = \frac{\text{GDP}}{\text{Population}} \tag{4}
\]
For real GDP per capita:
\[
\text{Real GDP per capita} = \frac{\text{Real GDP}}{\text{Population}} \tag{5}
\]


Code
countries <- tibble(
  Country = c("United States", "China", "Norway"),
  `Nominal GDP ($B)` = c(29168, 18533, 579),
  Population_M = c(340, 1425, 5.5),
  Deflator = c(123.5, 115.0, 120.0)
) %>%
  mutate(
    `Real GDP ($B)` = round(`Nominal GDP ($B)` / (Deflator / 100)),
    `Nominal per Capita` = round(`Nominal GDP ($B)` * 1e3 / Population_M),
    `Real per Capita` = round(`Real GDP ($B)` * 1e3 / Population_M)
  )

countries %>%
  transmute(
    Country,
    `Nominal GDP` = paste0("$", format(`Nominal GDP ($B)`, big.mark = ","), " B"),
    `Population` = paste0(Population_M, " M"),
    `Nominal per Capita` = dollar(`Nominal per Capita`),
    `Real per Capita (2017$)` = dollar(`Real per Capita`)
  ) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrrr",
        caption = "GDP per Capita: US vs. China vs. Norway (approx. 2024)") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)



GDP per Capita: US vs. China vs. Norway (approx. 2024)

The China Paradox



China has the largest economy in the world by PPP, but its GDP per capita is roughly 1/5th of Norway‚Äôs and 1/6th of the US. Total GDP measures the size of the economy. Per capita GDP measures the standard of living of individuals. These are fundamentally different questions.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
2.4 Purchasing Power Parity (PPP)
Even after adjusting for inflation and population, comparing across countries using market exchange rates is misleading. A haircut costs $25 in Las Cruces but ¬•30 (about $4) in rural China. If a Chinese worker earns $13,000 per year in nominal terms, that money buys far more stuff in China than it would in the US.
Purchasing Power Parity adjusts for these price differences by using a hypothetical ‚Äúinternational dollar‚Äù ‚Äî a currency that has the same purchasing power everywhere.
\[
\text{GDP}_{PPP} = \text{GDP}_{\text{local currency}} \times \frac{\text{PPP conversion factor}}{\text{Market exchange rate}} \tag{6}
\]
Or more intuitively:
\[
\text{GDP per capita (PPP)} = \frac{\text{GDP (PPP)}}{\text{Population}} \tag{7}
\]


Code
ppp_data <- tibble(
  Country = c("United States", "China", "Norway"),
  `Nominal per Capita (USD)` = c(85780, 13000, 105240),
  `PPP per Capita (Int$)` = c(85780, 24500, 92600),
  `PPP Multiplier` = c(1.00, 1.88, 0.88)
)

ppp_data %>%
  mutate(
    `Nominal per Capita (USD)` = dollar(`Nominal per Capita (USD)`),
    `PPP per Capita (Int$)` = dollar(`PPP per Capita (Int$)`),
    `PPP Multiplier` = paste0(format(`PPP Multiplier`, nsmall = 2), "x")
  ) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "Nominal vs. PPP-Adjusted GDP per Capita (approx. 2024)") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
2.5 The Complete Conversion Pipeline
Putting it all together, here‚Äôs the full chain from raw output to a meaningful cross-country comparison:
\[
\text{Nominal GDP} \xrightarrow{\div \text{Deflator}} \text{Real GDP} \xrightarrow{\div \text{Population}} \text{Real GDP per Capita} \xrightarrow{\times \text{PPP adj.}} \text{Real GDP per Capita (PPP)} \tag{8}
\]


Code
pipeline <- tibble(
  Step = c("1. Nominal GDP", "2. √∑ GDP Deflator", "3. √∑ Population", "4. √ó PPP Adjustment"),
  `What It Removes` = c("(Raw measure)", "Inflation", "Size differences", "Price-level differences"),
  `US Example` = c("$29.2 T", "$23.6 T (2017$)", "$69,400", "$85,780"),
  `China Example` = c("$18.5 T", "$16.1 T (2017$)", "$11,300", "$24,500"),
  `Norway Example` = c("$579 B", "$483 B (2017$)", "$87,700", "$92,600")
)

pipeline %>%
  kable(align = "llrrr",
        caption = "The GDP Conversion Pipeline") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE) %>%
  row_spec(4, bold = TRUE, background = "#f0f9e8")

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
3.1 Measuring Growth
Economic growth is measured as the percent change in real GDP per capita:
\[
g_t = \frac{y_t - y_{t-1}}{y_{t-1}} \times 100 \tag{9}
\]
where \(g_t\) is the growth rate and \(y_t\) is real GDP per capita in year \(t\).


Code
# China growth example
y_2023 <- 21600
y_2024 <- 22700

g_china <- (y_2024 - y_2023) / y_2023 * 100

cat("China PPP per capita growth ‚âà", round(g_china, 1), "%")


China PPP per capita growth ‚âà 5.1 %

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
3.2 The Rule of 70
Small differences in growth rates produce enormous differences over time because of compounding. The Rule of 70 tells you how long it takes for a variable to double:
\[
\text{Doubling Time (years)} = \frac{70}{\text{Annual Growth Rate (\%)}} \tag{10}
\]


Code
growth_rates <- tibble(
  Country = c("United States", "China", "Norway"),
  `Approx. Growth Rate (%)` = c(2.0, 5.0, 1.5),
) %>%
  mutate(
    `Doubling Time (years)` = round(70 / `Approx. Growth Rate (%)`, 1),
    `GDP per Capita in 35 years (multiple)` = round((1 + `Approx. Growth Rate (%)`/100)^35, 2)
  )

growth_rates %>%
  mutate(`GDP per Capita in 35 years (multiple)` = paste0(`GDP per Capita in 35 years (multiple)`, "x")) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "The Rule of 70: Growth Rates and Doubling Times") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)



The Rule of 70: Growth Rates and Doubling Times


Country
Approx. Growth Rate (%)
Doubling Time (years)
GDP per Capita in 35 years (multiple)

1.68x











Why Growth Rates Are Everything



At 2% growth, the US doubles its living standard every 35 years. At 5% growth, China doubles every 14 years. This is why China went from one of the poorest countries to the world‚Äôs largest economy (PPP) in just four decades. Compound growth is the most powerful force in economics.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
section: 3.3 Compounding: The FV Formula Applied to GDP
text:
3.3 Compounding: The FV Formula Applied to GDP
The same Future Value formula from our Tesla lecture applies here. If a country‚Äôs real GDP per capita is \(y_0\) today and it grows at rate \(g\) per year:
\[
y_n = y_0 \times (1 + g)^n \tag{11}
\]


Code
years_ahead <- c(10, 20, 35, 50)

projections <- expand_grid(
  Country = c("United States", "China", "Norway"),
  Years = years_ahead
) %>%
  mutate(
    y0 = case_when(
      Country == "United States" ~ 85780,
      Country == "China" ~ 24500,
      Country == "Norway" ~ 92600
    ),
    g = case_when(
      Country == "United States" ~ 0.02,
      Country == "China" ~ 0.05,
      Country == "Norway" ~ 0.015
    ),
    `Projected PPP per Capita` = round(y0 * (1 + g)^Years)
  )

projections %>%
  mutate(`Projected PPP per Capita` = dollar(`Projected PPP per Capita`)) %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = Years, values_from = `Projected PPP per Capita`,
              names_prefix = "Year ") %>%
  select(-y0, -g) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrrr",
        caption = "Projected GDP per Capita (PPP) at Current Growth Rates") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

Convergence Alert



At these growth rates, China‚Äôs GDP per capita would surpass Norway‚Äôs in roughly 30 years and approach the US level in about 35. But will China maintain 5% growth? The Solow model says no ‚Äî diminishing returns to capital will slow it down as China moves from catch-up to cutting-edge growth.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
4.1 The Golden Age (1950‚Äì1973)
The period after WWII was one of the greatest economic expansions in history. Average global growth hit 4.8% per year ‚Äî a pace never seen before or since.


Code
postwar <- tibble(
  Country = c("United States", "China", "Norway",
              "Japan", "Germany", "United Kingdom"),
  `Growth Rate 1950‚Äì1973 (%)` = c(3.93, 4.90, 4.06,
                                    9.29, 5.68, 2.93),
  `Growth Rate 1973‚Äì2000 (%)` = c(2.99, 7.50, 3.35,
                                    2.97, 2.01, 2.18),
  `Growth Rate 2000‚Äì2024 (%)` = c(1.80, 8.20, 1.30,
                                    0.70, 1.10, 1.40)
)

postwar %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "Average Annual GDP Growth Rates by Era") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE) %>%
  row_spec(which(postwar$Country %in% c("United States", "China", "Norway")),
           bold = TRUE, background = "#f0f9e8")

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
section: 4.2 The US Story: Slow and Steady Wins the Race
text:
4.2 The US Story: Slow and Steady Wins the Race
The United States never had the fastest growth rate in any era. Its power comes from consistency ‚Äî roughly 2‚Äì4% growth sustained over more than 200 years. From 1950 to 1975, US GDP went from $228 billion to $1.7 trillion, and by 1975 the US represented about 35% of world industrial output.
The US advantage: strong institutions, rule of law, property rights, deep capital markets, and a culture of innovation. These are exactly the factors Cowen & Tabarrok identify as the foundations of wealth.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
section: 4.3 The China Story: The Greatest Catch-Up in History
text:
4.3 The China Story: The Greatest Catch-Up in History
In 1950, China‚Äôs GDP per capita was roughly comparable to sub-Saharan Africa. After Mao‚Äôs death and Deng Xiaoping‚Äôs reforms in 1978, China began the most dramatic economic transformation in recorded history:

Switched from communal to individual farming ‚Üí food production increased 50%
Opened to foreign trade and investment
Invested massively in physical capital (factories, infrastructure, cities)
Growth averaged nearly 10% per year for three decades

By 2020, China‚Äôs total GDP (PPP) surpassed the United States. But per capita, China is still roughly where the US was in the early 2000s.


Code
china_trajectory <- tibble(
  Year = c(1950, 1978, 1990, 2000, 2010, 2020, 2024),
  `China GDP/capita (PPP, 2017$)` = c(637, 1517, 2982, 4500, 10200, 17200, 24500),
  `US GDP/capita (PPP, 2017$)` = c(15241, 25368, 35762, 44700, 49300, 55800, 85780),
  `China as % of US` = NA
) %>%
  mutate(`China as % of US` = paste0(round(`China GDP/capita (PPP, 2017$)` /
                                             `US GDP/capita (PPP, 2017$)` * 100, 1), "%"))

china_trajectory %>%
  mutate(across(contains("GDP"), ~dollar(.))) %>%
  kable(align = "rrrr",
        caption = "China's Catch-Up: GDP per Capita Relative to the US") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
section: 4.4 The Norway Story: Small, Rich, and Institutional
text:
4.4 The Norway Story: Small, Rich, and Institutional
Norway offers a fascinating counterpoint. With just 5.5 million people, it has:

GDP per capita that rivals or exceeds the US
A sovereign wealth fund (the Government Pension Fund Global) worth over $1.7 trillion ‚Äî funded by North Sea oil
World-class institutions: low corruption, strong property rights, high trust

Norway‚Äôs growth rate (1.5‚Äì4%) has never been spectacular. But like the US, it has been consistent, backed by institutions that the textbook describes as essential: property rights, honest government, political stability, a dependable legal system, and competitive markets.


Code
norway_comp <- tibble(
  Metric = c("GDP per Capita (Nominal)", "GDP per Capita (PPP)",
             "Population", "Sovereign Wealth Fund",
             "Transparency Intl. Rank", "Post-WWII Avg. Growth"),
  `Norway` = c("$105,240", "$92,600", "5.5 M", "$1.7 T",
               "Top 5 (least corrupt)", "~3.5%"),
  `United States` = c("$85,780", "$85,780", "340 M", "N/A",
                       "~25th", "~3.0%"),
  `China` = c("$13,000", "$24,500", "1,425 M", "$1.3 T (CIC)",
              "~80th", "~6.5% (post-1978)")
)

norway_comp %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "Norway vs. US vs. China: Key Indicators") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
5.1 Capital Accumulation and Diminishing Returns
The Solow model explains why catch-up growth eventually slows. The production function is:
\[
Y = F(A, K, eL) \tag{12}
\]
where \(Y\) = output, \(A\) = ideas/technology, \(K\) = physical capital, \(e\) = education (human capital), and \(L\) = labor.
If we hold \(A\), \(e\), and \(L\) constant, output depends only on capital:
\[
Y = \sqrt{K} \tag{13}
\]
The key insight: diminishing marginal returns to capital. The first factory in a poor country is incredibly productive. The 10,000th factory adds much less.


Code
capital_data <- tibble(
  K = seq(0, 500, by = 25)
) %>%
  mutate(
    Y = sqrt(K),
    MPK = ifelse(K > 0, 1 / (2 * sqrt(K)), NA)
  )

# Show the key values
capital_data %>%
  filter(K %in% c(1, 25, 100, 225, 400)) %>%
  mutate(
    `Capital (K)` = K,
    `Output (Y = ‚àöK)` = round(Y, 2),
    `MPK (additional output per unit K)` = round(MPK, 4)
  ) %>%
  select(-K, -Y, -MPK) %>%
  kable(align = "rrr",
        caption = "Diminishing Returns: More Capital ‚Üí Less Additional Output") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)



Diminishing Returns: More Capital ‚Üí Less Additional Output


Capital (K)
Output (Y = ‚àöK)
MPK (additional output per unit K)

0.0500

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
5.2 The Steady State
In the Solow model, capital grows when investment > depreciation and shrinks when depreciation > investment.
\[
K_{t+1} = K_t + \text{Investment}_t - \text{Depreciation}_t \tag{14}
\]
\[
\text{Investment} = \gamma \times Y \tag{15}
\]
\[
\text{Depreciation} = \delta \times K \tag{16}
\]
where \(\gamma\) = investment rate (fraction of output invested) and \(\delta\) = depreciation rate.
Steady state occurs when investment exactly replaces depreciation:
\[
\gamma \times Y = \delta \times K \tag{17}
\]
At this point, the capital stock stops growing, and so does output. Capital accumulation alone cannot explain long-run growth.


Code
# Simulate the Solow model
gamma <- 0.30  # investment rate
delta <- 0.02  # depreciation rate

solow_sim <- tibble(Period = 0:100) %>%
  mutate(K = NA_real_, Y = NA_real_, Investment = NA_real_, Depreciation = NA_real_)

solow_sim$K[1] <- 10  # start with very little capital (like China in 1978)
solow_sim$Y[1] <- sqrt(10)
solow_sim$Investment[1] <- gamma * solow_sim$Y[1]
solow_sim$Depreciation[1] <- delta * solow_sim$K[1]

for (t in 2:nrow(solow_sim)) {
  solow_sim$K[t] <- solow_sim$K[t-1] + solow_sim$Investment[t-1] - solow_sim$Depreciation[t-1]
  solow_sim$Y[t] <- sqrt(solow_sim$K[t])
  solow_sim$Investment[t] <- gamma * solow_sim$Y[t]
  solow_sim$Depreciation[t] <- delta * solow_sim$K[t]
}

# Show key periods
solow_sim %>%
  filter(Period %in% c(0, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60, 80, 100)) %>%

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
6.1 Why Capital Isn‚Äôt Enough
The Solow model‚Äôs most important prediction: capital accumulation alone cannot explain long-run growth. The US has been growing for 200+ years ‚Äî that can‚Äôt be diminishing-returns capital accumulation. It must be something else.
That something is ideas (\(A\) in the production function).
\[
Y = A \times F(K, eL) \tag{18}
\]
An increase in \(A\) shifts the entire production function upward ‚Äî you get more output from the same capital and labor. A modern computer has roughly the same silicon as one from 2005, but it‚Äôs enormously more productive. The difference is ideas.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
6.2 Ideas Are Non-Rivalrous
Ideas are fundamentally different from physical goods:








Property
Physical Capital (a tractor)
Ideas (the wheel)




Rivalrous?
Yes ‚Äî if I use it, you can‚Äôt
No ‚Äî your use doesn‚Äôt diminish mine


Depreciates?
Yes ‚Äî wears out over time
No ‚Äî once discovered, persists forever


Shareable?
Expensive to duplicate
Nearly free to share


Returns?
Diminishing
Potentially increasing



This non-rivalry is why ideas are the only factor that can sustain long-run growth. But it creates a problem: if ideas are free to copy, why would anyone invest in creating them?

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
6.3 The Patent Trade-Off
Patents create a temporary monopoly (typically 20 years) to incentivize R&D. But monopoly power raises prices and slows the spread of ideas. This is one of the trickiest trade-offs in economic policy.
Norway and the US both have strong intellectual property systems. China has historically been weaker on IP protection, which makes it easier to catch up (copy existing ideas) but harder to innovate at the frontier.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
6.4 Institutions That Drive Innovation
The textbook identifies the key institutions:

Property rights ‚Äî if your invention will be stolen, why invent?
Honest government ‚Äî corruption is a tax on entrepreneurs
Political stability ‚Äî investors need predictable rules
Dependable legal system ‚Äî contracts must be enforceable
Competitive and open markets ‚Äî trade expands the market for ideas



Code
inst_data <- tibble(
  Institution = c("Property Rights", "Corruption (TI Rank, lower = cleaner)",
                   "Ease of Business", "R&D as % of GDP", "Patent Applications (annual)"),
  `United States` = c("Strong", "~25th", "High", "3.5%", "~600,000"),
  China = c("Improving", "~80th", "Moderate", "2.6%", "~1,600,000"),
  Norway = c("Very Strong", "~4th", "Very High", "2.3%", "~2,000")
)

inst_data %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "Institutional Comparison") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
7.1 What It Means
Conditional convergence is the tendency ‚Äî among countries with similar institutions ‚Äî for poorer countries to grow faster than richer ones. This is exactly what the Solow model predicts: countries far below their steady state grow fast (high MPK), while countries near steady state grow slowly.
Among OECD countries (which share broadly similar institutions), this pattern holds almost perfectly: the poorest members in 1960 grew fastest over the next 40 years.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
7.2 China‚Äôs Convergence Question
China‚Äôs growth fits the catch-up story perfectly ‚Äî but the ‚Äúconditional‚Äù part matters. Convergence only happens if a country has the institutions to sustain it. China has invested heavily in capital and education, but faces challenges:

Poor banking system (state-directed lending, shadow banking)
Limited rule of law
Aging population (demographic headwind)
Transition from imitation to innovation is hard

The Solow model predicts China‚Äôs growth will slow as it approaches its steady state. The question is whether institutional reforms will raise that steady state ‚Äî or whether it will plateau below US levels.

title: The Wealth of Nations and Economic Growth
text:
7.3 Norway‚Äôs Lesson
Norway shows that you don‚Äôt need fast growth to be rich. You need consistent growth backed by excellent institutions. Norway grew at 4% during the post-war boom, slowed to 1.5‚Äì3% since, and is still one of the wealthiest countries per capita on Earth. The sovereign wealth fund ‚Äî investing oil revenues rather than spending them ‚Äî is an institutional innovation in itself.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
You‚Äôve found your dream car: a 2023 Tesla Model X Plaid in black with a white interior, listed at $65,000. Before you sign anything, you need to understand exactly what this purchase will cost you ‚Äî not just the sticker price, but the total cost of borrowing over time.
This is the time value of money in action. A dollar today is worth more than a dollar tomorrow, because today‚Äôs dollar can earn interest. When you borrow money, the lender charges you for the privilege of using their dollars now and paying them back later.

New Mexico Vehicle Fees



New Mexico charges a 4% Motor Vehicle Excise Tax on the sale price (not the full GRT). Title is $10. Registration for a heavy passenger vehicle (the Model X Plaid weighs ~5,185 lbs) runs about $62/year. There is no separate ‚Äúsales tax‚Äù on vehicles ‚Äî the excise tax replaces it.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
2.1 Future Value (FV)
Question: If I invest $65,672 today, what will it be worth in \(n\) years at interest rate \(i\)?
\[
FV = PV \times (1 + i)^{n} \tag{1}
\]
where:

\(FV\) = future value (what you‚Äôll have/owe at the end)
\(PV\) = present value (the amount today)
\(i\) = interest rate per period (as a decimal)
\(n\) = number of compounding periods



Code
PV <- 65672
i_easy <- 0.10
i_real <- 0.0748
n_5 <- 5
n_7 <- 7

FV_easy_5 <- PV * (1 + i_easy)^n_5
FV_easy_7 <- PV * (1 + i_easy)^n_7
FV_real_5 <- PV * (1 + i_real)^n_5
FV_real_7 <- PV * (1 + i_real)^n_7

tibble(
  Scenario = c("10% / 5-year", "10% / 7-year", "7.48% / 5-year", "7.48% / 7-year"),
  `PV (Loan)` = scales::dollar(PV),
  Rate = c("10.00%", "10.00%", "7.48%", "7.48%"),
  Years = c(5, 7, 5, 7),
  `FV (Total Owed if No Payments)` = scales::dollar(c(FV_easy_5, FV_easy_7, FV_real_5, FV_real_7))
) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrrr", caption = "Future Value of $65,672 at Different Rates and Terms") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
2.2 Present Value (PV)
Question: What is a future payment worth today? This is the inverse of FV.
\[
PV = \frac{FV}{(1 + i)^{n}} \tag{2}
\]
This is exactly what Mishkin means when he says ‚Äúa dollar paid to you one year from now is less valuable than a dollar paid to you today.‚Äù The denominator \((1+i)^n\) is the discount factor ‚Äî it shrinks the future value back to today‚Äôs dollars.


Code
# What is a $100,000 payment 5 years from now worth today?
FV_example <- 100000

PV_easy <- FV_example / (1 + i_easy)^n_5
PV_real <- FV_example / (1 + i_real)^n_5

tibble(
  Scenario = c("At 10%", "At 7.48%"),
  `Future Payment` = scales::dollar(FV_example),
  `Years Away` = 5,
  `Present Value Today` = scales::dollar(c(PV_easy, PV_real)),
  `You "Lose"` = scales::dollar(FV_example - c(PV_easy, PV_real))
) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrrr",
        caption = "Present Value of $100,000 Received in 5 Years") %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE)

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
2.3 Payment (PMT) ‚Äî The Fixed-Payment Loan Formula
This is the formula that actually determines your monthly car payment. It comes from the fixed-payment loan equation in Mishkin Chapter 4:
\[
PMT = PV \times \frac{i}{1 - (1 + i)^{-n}} \tag{3}
\]
where:

\(PMT\) = fixed payment per period
\(PV\) = loan principal (amount financed)
\(i\) = interest rate per period (monthly rate if paying monthly)
\(n\) = total number of payments (months if paying monthly)







Annuity Connection



This is the annuity formula rearranged. The loan is the present value of all your future payments, discounted at the interest rate. The lender is buying an annuity (your stream of payments) and paying you the lump sum now.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
3.1 Time Conversion
\[
n_{\text{months}} = n_{\text{years}} \times 12 \tag{4}
\]
\[
n_{\text{years}} = \frac{n_{\text{months}}}{12} \tag{5}
\]



Loan Term

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
3.2 Interest Rate Conversion
Annual Percentage Rate (APR) to monthly rate:
\[
i_{\text{monthly}} = \frac{i_{\text{annual}}}{12} \tag{6}
\]
To go back:
\[
i_{\text{annual}} = i_{\text{monthly}} \times 12 \tag{7}
\]


Code
tibble(
  Scenario = c("Scenario A (easy math)", "Scenario B (realistic)"),
  `Annual Rate` = c("10.00%", "7.48%"),
  `Monthly Rate` = paste0(round(c(0.10/12, 0.0748/12) * 100, 4), "%"),
  `Monthly Rate (decimal)` = round(c(0.10/12, 0.0748/12), 6)
) %>%
  kable(align = "lrrr",
        caption = "Annual to Monthly Rate Conversion") %>%

Common Mistake



Students frequently forget to convert the annual rate to monthly before plugging into the PMT formula. If you use \(i = 0.10\) instead of \(i = 0.10/12 = 0.00833\), your payment will be wildly wrong.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
7.1 How Amortization Works
Each month:

Interest portion = Remaining Balance √ó Monthly Rate
Principal portion = Payment ‚àí Interest Portion
New Balance = Old Balance ‚àí Principal Portion

\[
\text{Interest}_t = \text{Balance}_{t-1} \times i_{\text{monthly}} \tag{8}
\]
\[
\text{Principal}_t = PMT - \text{Interest}_t \tag{9}
\]
\[
\text{Balance}_t = \text{Balance}_{t-1} - \text{Principal}_t \tag{10}
\]


Code
build_amortization <- function(pv, annual_rate, years, label) {
  monthly_rate <- annual_rate / 12
  n_months <- years * 12
  pmt <- pv * (monthly_rate / (1 - (1 + monthly_rate)^(-n_months)))

  balance <- pv
  schedule <- tibble(
    Month = integer(),
    Payment = numeric(),
    Interest = numeric(),
    Principal = numeric(),
    Balance = numeric()
  )

  for (m in 1:n_months) {
    interest <- balance * monthly_rate
    principal <- pmt - interest
    balance <- balance - principal

    schedule <- schedule %>% add_row(
      Month = m,
      Payment = round(pmt, 2),
      Interest = round(interest, 2),
      Principal = round(principal, 2),
      Balance = round(max(balance, 0), 2)
    )
  }

  schedule$Scenario <- label
  return(schedule)
}

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
10.1 The Fixed-Payment Loan (Ch. 4)
Your auto loan is a fixed-payment loan ‚Äî one of the four credit market instruments Mishkin describes. The loan value equals the present value of all future payments:
\[
LV = \frac{FP}{(1+i)} + \frac{FP}{(1+i)^2} + \frac{FP}{(1+i)^3} + \cdots + \frac{FP}{(1+i)^n} \tag{11}
\]
where \(LV\) = loan value, \(FP\) = fixed payment, \(i\) = interest rate, \(n\) = number of periods.
This is exactly the annuity present value formula. When we solve for \(FP\) (the payment), we get Equation (3) from earlier. The lender‚Äôs perspective: they‚Äôre buying a stream of your future payments at a price equal to the loan amount.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
10.2 The Inverse Relationship (Ch. 4‚Äì5)
Mishkin‚Äôs key insight: price and yield move inversely. For your auto loan:

If market rates drop after you lock in at 10%, your loan becomes expensive relative to new loans ‚Äî you‚Äôre overpaying (an incentive to refinance)
If market rates rise, your locked-in rate looks like a bargain

This is the same inverse relationship that governs bond prices.

title: Time Value of Money: Buying a Tesla
text:
10.3 Interest Rate Risk
If you took the 7-year loan at 7.48% and rates drop to 5% after two years, you face a decision: refinance (pay closing costs, get lower rate) or keep paying. This is interest-rate risk applied to consumer finance ‚Äî the same concept Mishkin discusses for bonds, just in your driveway.
